thread.title: LSU expects real Tiger Stadium experience for Florida
thread.title_full: LSU expects real Tiger Stadium experience for Florida

title: LSU expects real Tiger Stadium experience for Florida
text:
LSU expects real Tiger Stadium experience for Florida Glenn Guilbeau 5:53 p.m. CDT October 16, 2015 South Carolina linebacker T.J. Holloman (11) attempts to tackle LSU running back Leonard Fournette (7) during the first half of last week’s game. (Photo: AP) 
BATON ROUGE – One week after 60,263 did not show at Tiger Stadium for a Southeastern Conference game, a capacity crowd of 102,321 is expected at the LSU-Florida game Saturday night at Tiger Stadium. 
The No. 6 Tigers (5-0, 3-0 Southeastern Conference) host the No. 8 Gators (6-0, 4-0 SEC) at 6 p.m. on ESPN one week after LSU received an extra home date when its game at South Carolina was moved here just three days before game day because of flooding in the Palmetto state. The box office was reopened from scratch, and just 42,058 showed on the short notice with events such as weddings, fishing trips and the like scheduled months in advance. LSU’s opponent was also not as worthy as Florida as the Gamecocks came in at 2-3 and 0-3 before losing, 45-24. 
“The game that passed, it felt like the spring game,” LSU tailback Leonard Fournette said this week. 
This Saturday is different. LSU will be hosting a top-10 pairing for the first time since the No. 5 Tigers lost to No. 1 Alabama, 21-17, in the final moments nearly three years ago. The Tigers lost their first scheduled home game to weather and have won their three previous three home games by an average 22 points. This one projects to be much closer as LSU is a touchdown favorite. 
Fournette, who graced the cover of Sports Illustrated this week as he is running away with the Heisman Trophy early forecasts, has never played in such a nationally significant game with SEC West, SEC Championship Game and College Football Playoffs implications. 
“It’s going to be crazy this weekend,” he said. “It’s a special moment, man. And I want you all to know, the tickets cost $110. I tried to buy one for my auntie. I told her I couldn’t do it. It cost $110. I want you all to know that.” 
All major college football players are given a limited number of tickets for family and friends. 
“Yeah, but my family’s big,” Fournette said. “She has to wait. I don’t know. I need a sale. I need the price to go down. But the price went up. So, next game, auntie.” 
LSU tickets are more expensive for premium home games such as Florida. Fournette’s extended family members may have to be satisfied with the lower priced tickets for Western Kentucky a week from today. 
“It’s going to be a great atmosphere out there,” Fournette said. “Coming out there and competing, man, ain’t no better feeling than playing in Tiger Stadium.” 
Things just did not feel right last week as the SEC office and LSU’s athletic department billed the game as South Carolina’s home game, and LSU generously applied various window dressings to make the Gamecocks feel at home. Kickoff was also at 2:30 p.m. 
“It wasn’t really arousing to us,” Fournette said. “But I know for sure, this game is going to be crazy. It’s going to be very intense.” 
The sun is expected to set Saturday at 6:33 p.m., likely during the first quarter. Temperatures will be in the high 60s or low 70s. 
“It will be dusk,” LSU coach Les Miles said wistfully. “There will be the opportunity for night to arrive, and this should be a great game, a very competitive game. This is a top-10 matchup. This is Tiger Stadium at its best, and we expect that the fishing trips are done. We are coming to Tiger Stadium.” 
Florida will be without blossoming freshman quarterback Will Grier because of a season suspension he received on Monday for taking performance enhancing drugs. But sophomore Treon Harris is a dual threat who started the season opener and six games last season. 
“That’s what is fun about coaching is putting the pieces together for the guys that are in there,” first-year Florida coach Jim McElwain, a former two-time national champion Alabama offensive coordinator, said. 
The Gators also field the SEC’s No. 2 defense against the run with 99.2 yards allowed a game, while Fournette is the nation’s leading rusher with 1,022 yards and 204 yards a game. 
“Well, I know I couldn’t tackle him,” McElwain said. “Very excited about the opportunity to go into a great place to play at night against a team that obviously is as good as anyone in the country. They do things right, and they know how to win.” 
LSU and Florida will meet as top-10 teams for the fifth time since 2006. The winner of this game won the national championship or reached the national championship game in 2006, ’07, ’08 and ’11. 
“We’re just ready to play. They’re going to be here Saturday. We’re going to be there. So whatever happens, happens,” LSU safety Rickey Jefferson said. 
“This is why you come here,” LSU defensive tackle Christian LaCouture said. “Both physical football teams trying to move up in the standings and trying to get in the College Football Playoff. Doesn’t get much better than this.” 10 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/sports/college/lsu/2015/10/16/lsu-expects-real-tiger-stadium-experience-florida/74082770/ TOP VIDEOS
